summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, responding to defense complaints in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The government defends its discovery efforts, states it has produced over 350,000 pages and anticipates producing over 1.2 million documents from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, and addresses issues regarding Maxwell's detention conditions at the MDC.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced (20 Cr. 330), who is the subject of the government's discovery productions and detention condition discussions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom this government letter is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced regarding the non-prosecution agreement from Florida and as the source of electronic discovery from his residences.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The signatory of the letter, representing the government's position.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged in connection with Epstein's activities; the government is producing discovery from devices seized from Epstein's residences for her case.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is leading the prosecution against Maxwell.

events.title: Defense Letter Filed
events.description: The defense submitted a letter raising accusations about discovery deficiencies and MDC conditions.

events.title: Discovery Deadline
events.description: Court-ordered deadline for the government to complete discovery productions in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Court Order on Discovery
events.description: The court issued an order directing the defense to renew discovery complaints only after the close of discovery if agreement with the government couldn't be reached.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY
Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY
keyFacts: The government states it has produced over 350,000 pages of Rule 16 discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense.
The government anticipates producing over 1.2 million documents from electronic devices seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences, with a target deadline of November 9, 2020.
The defense accused the government of abandoning discovery deadlines and mishandling discovery, which the government strongly denies.

The government addresses complaints about Maxwell's ability to review discovery at the MDC, stating it is working with MDC staff to resolve technical issues and that she has approximately 13 hours of daily access.

The letter references a prior non-prosecution agreement between the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and Jeffrey Epstein, which the defense claims contains exculpatory material, but the government argues is not relevant to Maxwell's case.
